title: Secret Essendon crisis meeting tapes at height of doping saga leaked - 9news.com.au
text:
Secret Essendon crisis meeting tapes at height of doping saga leaked By 9NEWS 
An explosive secret tape recording at the peak of the Essendon drugs saga has been released. 
The Herald Sun has published audio from the crisis meeting, which was held on August 8, 2013, just hours after the AFL told the club charges would be laid against it, former coach James Hird, football manager Danny Corcoran, club doctor Bruce Reid and possibly senior assistant Mark Thompson. 
In the recording, Hird, Thompson, Corcoran and club chairman Paul Little appear to be furious, suggesting they felt the AFL was threatening them to accept the sanctions or be stood down. 
"And that's where we're sort of headed now," Little can be heard saying. 
"Because one thing that Ray (Gunston) and I have learnt in the last few days … is that they've absolutely said one thing and done the opposite … and every single issue that I agreed on with (then AFL deputy chief) Gil McLachlan, and I met with him the other night, has pretty much been reversed now in this note here." A secret recording of a meeting between James Hird, Danny Corcoran, Paul Little and Mark Thompson has been released. (AAP) 
Hird adds: "They're a pack of f---ing lying p and they have done from the start." 
Little spoke about how angry he was that McLachlan appeared to have "gone back" on his word. 
"I rang him last night and I said, 'You know you've really upset me here, because you've gone back on your word, Gil'. 
"He said, 'No, no I haven't, I haven't.' I said 'You have. You told me one thing, and now you're doing something else'." 
The newspaper reports Corcoran, Thompson, Hird and Little gave their approval for the once-secret tape to be released to the public. 
Five days after its recording, Hird, Thompson, Corcoran and Reid were all charged by the AFL with brining the game into disrepute. 
Essendon was slapped with a $2 million fine, wasn’t allowed to play in the finals and was stripped of draft picks. 
The release of the tape has promoted federal Labor MP Kimberley Kitching to join a push for a senate inquiry into the conduct of the AFL and ASADA. 
"It is clear mistakes were made by regulators and other and those mistakes must never be repeated," Senator Kitching told the Herald. © Nine Digital Pty Ltd 2017
